describe: A souvenir is something you buy to remind you of a place or event.
sample: → I bought a Russian doll as a souvenir from my trip to Moscow.

describe: A submarine is a boat that can go underwater for long periods of time.
sample: → The submarine dove under the sea so the enemy couldn’t see it.

describe: To trace something means to follow over it with the eyes or a finger.
sample: → He traced over the graph with his finger.

describe: An appliance is a piece of equipment used for jobs in the home.
sample: → Many homes have appliances like ovens, toasters and refrigerators.

describe: A basin is large bowl for washing things. A sink is sometimes called a basin.
sample: → She filled the basin with water and washed her face.

describe: A broom is a brush with a long handle used for cleaning floors.
sample: → My father usually uses a broom to sweep away dust in the basement.

describe: A caterpillar is a small insect that looks like a worm and eats plants.
sample: → After eating a lot of leaves, caterpillars change into butterflies.

describe: A cupboard is a piece of furniture that is used to store food or household items.
sample: → We put all of our dishes and food in the cupboards.

describe: If something or someone is delicate, they are easy to break or harm.
sample: → You should hold the baby carefully because she’s very delicate.

describe: To emerge from something means to come out of it.
sample: → The hand suddenly emerged from the grave.

describe: A handicap is a condition that limits someone’s mental or physical abilities.
sample: → Joe has a slight handicap, so he uses a walker to get around.

describe: A hook is a sharp curved piece of metal used for catching or holding things.
sample: → The fish went after the sharp hook.

describe: To hop means to jump a short distance.
sample: → The kangaroo quickly hopped away from danger.

describe: Laundry is clothes that have been or need to be washed.
sample: → He folded the clean laundry and put the dirty laundry in a basket.

describe: To pursue someone or something is to chase or follow them.
sample: → The mother pursued her young child down the hill.

describe: If someone is reluctant, they do not want to do something.
sample: → She was reluctant to eat the meager breakfast.

describe: Sleeves are the part of a shirt where your arms go.
sample: → Ryan bought a new shirt with long sleeves to keep his arms warm.

describe: The spine is the bone that runs up and down the middle of the back.
sample: → Our spine helps us to stand up nice and straight.

describe: A stain is a dirty mark that is difficult to clean.
sample: → He had a red stain on the collar of his shirt.

describe: A strip is a long, narrow piece of material or land.
sample: → He had long strips of film that held images of his trip abroad.

describe: To swear means to promise to do something.
sample: → I will put my hand on the Bible and swear to do my best for the country.

describe: To swing something means to move it back and forth or from side to side.
sample: → He can swing a golf club very powerfully.

describe: To utilize something means to use it for a specific purpose.
sample: → They utilized a pair of scissors to cut the ribbon.

describe: An aroma is a scent or smell.
sample: → I love the aroma of coffee in the morning.

describe: A beverage is a drink.
sample: → The waiter brought our beverages first. Then he brought our food.

describe: A cluster of things is a small group of them placed close together.
sample: → She held a large cluster of grapes in her hand.

describe: To combine is to join together to make a single thing or group.
sample: → Mina combined peanut butter and jelly to make a sandwich.

describe: When a liquid is condensed, it is made thicker.
sample: → One way to make a dessert thick and sweet is to use condensed milk.

describe: When something is contemporary, it is related to the present time.
sample: → Contemporary scientists have learned quite a bit about DNA.

describe: To cultivate plants is to care for them and help them grow.
sample: → A research company is cultivating new kinds of rice to aid poor countries.

describe: When something is divine, it is related to gods.
sample: → Legends say that music was given to men as a divine gift from the gods.

describe: When it is humid, there is a lot of water in the air.
sample: → It is very humid inside of a sauna.

describe: An odor is a very distinct smell.
sample: → He knew there was a leak when he noticed the strong odor of natural gas.

describe: The palate is the top part of the mouth.
sample: → You can touch your palate with your tongue.

describe: Paradise is the place or condition of happiness where things are perfect.
sample: → My vacation in Hawaii was like being in paradise.

describe: A plantation is a big farm that only grows certain kinds of crops.
sample: → In the 1800s, there were many cotton plantations in the southern US.

describe: When something is rapid, it moves or changes very quickly.
sample: → His mother was surprised by her son’s rapid growth.

describe: A rate is the speed at which something happens.
sample: → Grass tends to grow at a very slow rate.

describe: When something is soothing, it makes you calm or relaxed.
sample: → The soothing music helped the baby fall asleep.

describe: When something is subtle, it is not easy to see or notice.
sample: → The handsome man has a subtle smile.

describe: The texture of something is the way its surface looks and feels.
sample: → The texture of a rock found in the water is typically very smooth.

describe: When something is toxic, it is poisonous. Toxic things are very dangerous.
sample: → Please check the label to see if the product is toxic.

describe: To vary means to be different from another thing in size or amount.
sample: → The heights of the people in my class vary by a large amount.

describe: An accident is an unexpected undesirable event.
sample: → She had to go to the hospital after she was in a serious car accident.

describe: An admiral is someone who controls many military ships.
sample: → They won the sea battle because of the admiral’s great leadership.

describe: An arc is a curved shape.
sample: → A rainbow has the shape of an arc.

describe: Your character is your personality.
sample: → My sister’s character is fun and very outgoing.

describe: Your conscience is your inner sense of what is right and wrong.
sample: → I recycle everything I can, so my conscience is clear!

describe: If something is fiery, it is burning strongly.
sample: → The fiery blaze burned all night long.

describe: Flesh is the skin, muscle and fat on your body.
sample: → The zebra’s flesh has black and white stripes.

describe: A grapefruit is a fruit similar to an orange, but bigger and not as sweet.
sample: → Would you like a grapefruit with your breakfast?

describe: Hay is dry grass used to feed animals or used as a covering.
sample: → I need to buy some more hay for the horse to sleep on.

describe: If you are horrified, you are very shocked and feel upset.
sample: → I was horrified when I read about the old lady who was attacked.

describe: Kerosene is a type of oil. It is used in some lamps and stoves.
sample: → Many people in poor countries cook on kerosene stoves.

describe: A loop is a line made into the shape of a circle.
sample: → He made a loop with the rope and placed it over the post.

describe: A paddle is a piece of wood or plastic that moves a boat across water.
sample: → We need a paddle to help us move across the water.

describe: A raft is a floating platform made from pieces of wood tied together.
sample: → The man made a raft out of bamboo and floated out to sea.

describe: When something is sour, it has a sharp and unpleasant taste.
sample: → I don’t like lemons because I think they are too sour.

describe: A stake is a small, sharp piece of wood or metal that is put into the ground.
sample: → We marked our property by placing stakes into the ground.

describe: A steward is a person like a waiter who serves food on planes and ships.
sample: → The steward is bringing some tea.

describe: String is a thin piece of fabric or rope.
sample: → I found a large ball of string.

describe: A thorn is a sharp part of a plant.
sample: → Be careful of the thorns when you pick the roses!

describe: To wreck something means to destroy or ruin it.
sample: → The teenagers wrecked the house for no reason at all.

describe: To admonish someone is to tell them you disapprove of their behavior.
sample: → The teacher admonished Mark because he was chewing gum in class.

describe: If something is audible, then it is able to be heard.
sample: → The sound of the drums was audible from miles away.

describe: If something or someone is awesome, they are impressive or frightening.
sample: → The huge military plane was an awesome sight.

describe: To beware means to be careful of something or someone that is dangerous.
sample: → You should beware of driving fast on wet roads.

describe: To brag means to talk of one’s abilities or achievements in a proud way.
sample: → He had strong muscles and bragged about it to the entire class.

describe: If someone is conscious of something, then they are aware of it.
sample: → The new student was conscious of the other students staring at her.

describe: To disagree with someone means to have a different opinion from them.
sample: → The lawyers disagreed about the best way to settle the case.

describe: To echo means that a sound repeats itself because it bounced off an object.
sample: → The child yelled over the canyon, and the wall echoed the sound.

describe: If something is eventual, it will happen at the end of a series of events.
sample: → The constant training and planning led the team to an eventual victory.

describe: A hint is information that suggests something will happen or is true.
sample: → I quietly passed on a hint to my sister about the test.

describe: An idiot is a person who is not smart or who has done something silly.
sample: → Because he got lost in the forest, the man felt like an idiot.

describe: If something is immense, it is very large.
sample: → An immense amount of money was needed to buy such a large boat.

describe: If something is indirect, then it is not the easiest or straightest way.
sample: → He chose to take the most indirect route to the coast.

describe: An option is a choice between two or more things.
sample: → The children were given the option of three houses to pick from.

describe: A pastime is an activity done for fun that you do often.
sample: → In the US, baseball is considered the national pastime.

describe: If something is perfect, then it is without any mistakes.
sample: → She got all the questions right, so her score was perfect.

describe: To pinpoint something means to locate it exactly.
sample: → The navigation system in my car is able to pinpoint my exact location.

describe: To switch means to change something to something else.
sample: → Mom switched the TV station from the news to her favorite show.

describe: If something or someone is thorough, then they are complete in every way.
sample: → Tina did a thorough job of cleaning the stains out of the carpet.

describe: To torment someone means to cause them to suffer on purpose.
sample: → She tormented her little brother by taking his favorite toy.

describe: A beak is the hard curved part of a bird’s mouth.
sample: → The bird used her beak to dig a small hole in the ground.

describe: If something is damp, it is somewhat wet.
sample: → My hair is still damp from my shower.

describe: To disapprove of something is to think that it is wrong.
sample: → Alex, disapproved of his son’s behavior.

describe: You use except to talk about the only thing that a statement does not apply to.
sample: → Everyone had fun on the trip except Jim, who felt ill the whole time.

describe: A flight is an act of flying, often in an airplane.
sample: → The airplane made a flight around the world.

describe: When someone is fond of something, they like it.
sample: → I am very fond of chocolate cake.

describe: When something or someone is immoral, they are evil or do bad things.
sample: → Stealing money from one’s mother is an immoral act.

describe: Ivy is a plant with long vines that grows upward typically on walls.
sample: → The walls of the castle are covered with ivy.

describe: To moan is to make a low sound when feeling pain or sadness.
sample: → The sick man moaned from his bed.

describe: If someone is oblivious of something, they are unaware of it.
sample: → I was late to school because I was oblivious of the time.

describe: To perish means to die, usually because of bad conditions or bad events.
sample: → Many people perish in wars.

describe: A pit is a big hole in the ground.
sample: → Michael fell into the pit and needed some help to get out.

describe: The rim is the outside edge of a round thing, like a cup or bottle.
sample: → I put my lips to the rim of the bottle and took a drink.

describe: A roost is a place where birds can land and rest or sleep.
sample: → The family of doves made a roost at the top of the tree.

describe: If something is slippery, it is wet or smooth and causes people to slip.
sample: → The repairman fell down on the floor because it was too slippery.

describe: To soar means to fly high in the air.
sample: → As the sun rose, two eagles soared through the sky.

describe: If something is trivial, it is not important or meaningful.
sample: → Television is trivial, but learning to read is very important.

describe: If something is typical, it is normal for a certain type of thing.
sample: → Barking is typical behavior for dogs.

describe: If something is utterly a way, it is completely that way.
sample: → When the sun was blocked by the moon, it was utterly dark outside.

describe: To weep means to cry.
sample: → My sister told me the dramatic movie would make me weep.

describe: If you do something awhile, you do it for a short time.
sample: → Wait here awhile, and I’ll bring some tea.

describe: Cyberspace is the imaginary place of the Internet where activities occur.
sample: → I didn’t receive your email. It probably got lost in cyberspace.

describe: To edit means to correct a piece of writing so that it is suitable to be published.
sample: → She asked her brother to edit her paper before she submitted it to her teacher.

describe: An essay is a short piece of writing on a certain subject.
sample: → She had to write a two-page essay for her English class.

describe: To evaluate something means to study it, so a decision can be made.
sample: → Joe and Ken evaluated the plan and agreed that it would work.

describe: To faint means to go unconscious and fall down.
sample: → Carol fainted because she hadn’t eaten in over a day.

describe: If something is global, it happens all around the world.
sample: → Pollution is a global problem.

describe: A gymnasium is a building with equipment that you can use to get exercise.
sample: → When I go to the gymnasium, I use the treadmill for 20 minutes.

describe: To highlight something means to mark it with a color so that it is easy to see.
sample: →  I read my vocabulary list and highlighted the most difficult words.

describe: If someone is ignorant about something, they have no knowledge about it.
sample: →  I’m a bit ignorant about his theories. Can you explain them to me?

describe: An index is a list of words at the end of a book that gives information.
sample: → If you look in the index, you’ll find the right page number.

describe: A lecture is a long, educational speech.
sample: → His lecture on world hunger was very informative.

describe: A moral is a message at the end of a story that teaches you something.
sample: → At the end of the story, Mother explained the moral to the children.

describe: To operate means to work or function.
sample: → I’m sorry, but the trains are not operating today.

describe: If something is private, it is only used by one person or group.
sample: → Don’t look at my diary! It’s private!

describe: When something is recent, it happened a short time ago.
sample: → I did not know what caused his recent behavior.

describe: A resolution is a personal decision.
sample: → At New Year, I made a list of resolutions to help me have a better year.

describe: A semester is a portion of a school year.
sample: → Jack is in his second semester of college.

describe: If something is typewritten, it is written on a computer or typewriter.
sample: → This is an important, formal project and must be typewritten.

describe: When something is weird, it is very strange.
sample: → My best friend’s dad is a bit weird.

describe: If something is absolute, it is total or complete.
sample: → My presentation was an absolute disaster! It was terrible!

describe: Alas is a word that people say when something bad happens.
sample: → I looked everywhere for my purse, but alas, I couldn’t find it.

describe: If you are attentive, you are careful and you pay attention.
sample: → He is a good student because he is attentive to every detail on his work.

describe: A cape is a large cloth that covers one’s back and is tied around the neck.
sample: → The superhero wore a long red cape.

describe: To envision something means to imagine that it may happen.
sample: → I can envision my mom’s face when I give her this present!

describe: When something happens evenly, it happens at the same rate or level.
sample: → The food was handed out evenly among the hungry people.

describe: Folk are common or average people.
sample: → I’ve invited all the folks from our street to a gathering at my place.

describe: To melt means to turn from a solid to a liquid.
sample: → The snowman that we made yesterday melted in the sun.

describe: A patch is a part of a surface that is different in appearance from the rest.
sample: → There was one small patch of grass in the sand-covered desert.

describe: Pleasure is a feeling of happiness.
sample: → The student smiled with pleasure when she received the prize.

describe: A pop is a short, loud sound.
sample: → I heard a loud pop; then my computer screen shattered.

describe: A pudding is a sweet dessert.
sample: → Would you like some chocolate pudding and coffee for dessert?

describe: A rail is a horizontal bar made of metal or wood.
sample: → The cat was sitting on the rail of the fence.

describe: A recipe is a set of instructions to make food.
sample: → The apple cake that you made is really tasty. Can I have the recipe, please?

describe: A role is the normal purpose or function of a person or thing.
sample: → My role at work is to check the quality of the products.

describe: To shrink means to get smaller.
sample: → If you stick to a healthy diet, your stomach will shrink!

describe: To soak something means to make it very wet.
sample: → You need to soak these beans overnight before you cook them.

describe: A spark is a small, quick flash of fire.
sample: → As he welded the two pieces of metal together, sparks flew everywhere.

describe: A spirit is someone’s feelings and personality, but not a physical body part.
sample: → He has a very outgoing spirit. He can make friends with anyone.

describe: A suit is a set of clothes. It usually includes a jacket with pants or a skirt.
sample: → I wore my new suit on my date with Melissa.

describe: An account with a bank is an arrangement to keep one’s money there.
sample: → After I paid for the new car, my bank account was nearly empty.

describe: An architect is a person who designs buildings.
sample: → The plans for building the new home were drawn by a famous architect.

describe: To conceal something means to hide it.
sample: → You should conceal your money so no one can take it from you.

describe: A crime is something bad that a person does that can be punished by law.
sample: → Police quickly arrived at the scene of the crime.

describe: A deed is a certificate that proves that someone owns something.
sample: → When she bought the car, she was given a deed to show the car was hers.

describe: Gratitude is a feeling of being thankful.
sample: → The kids showed Aunt Tess much gratitude for visiting them.

describe: A habitat is the natural home of animals or plants.
sample: → Frogs are often found in a wet habitat, such as near a lake, river, or pond.

describe: To intervene means to help stop a problem between two people or groups.
sample: → The students argued until the teacher intervened.

describe: A landmark is an object that helps people find or remember a location.
sample: → The tall tree was used as a landmark for people to find the road to the inn.

describe: If something is legal, it is related to the law or allowed by the law.
sample: → It was not legal for him to drive until he was eighteen years old.

describe: If something is memorable, then it is remembered for a special reason.
sample: → The party was memorable; people were still talking about it years later.

describe: To oblige someone means to require them to do something.
sample: → If I wanted to have playtime, I was obliged to clean my room once a week.

describe: An offense is an action that breaks the law and requires punishment.
sample: → He was put in jail for two days for the offense.

describe: To proclaim something means to say it in public.
sample: → The army general proclaimed that the war was won.

describe: A rally is a large public meeting in order to support something.
sample: → The school had a rally in the gym to support the basketball team.

describe: To resolve something means to find a solution.
sample: → She resolved the problem with her children by giving them both a toy.

describe: Resources are a person or country’s money and materials that they can use.
sample: → The poor man didn’t have the resources to feed himself.

describe: A sentence is punishment given to someone who didn’t follow the law.
sample: → The sentence for stealing a car is much worse than for stealing candy.

describe: To volunteer means to offer to do something for free.
sample: → Many people volunteered to help the adults learn to read.

describe: A witness is someone who sees or hears a crime or accident happen.
sample: → The woman was the only witness of the horrible crime.

describe: Access is the right to enter or use something.
sample: → The manager was the only person with access to the password.

describe: Conduct is the way that someone acts.
sample: → She was punished for her bad conduct.

describe: When an event or action is constant, it happens a lot or all the time.
sample: → The television at home is in constant use.

describe: A crack is a narrow space between the parts of something broken.
sample: → The old window was covered with cracks.

describe: A device is an object or a machine.
sample: → A thermometer is a device that tells temperature.

describe: To enclose something is to contain it.
sample: → The cows in the field were enclosed by a fence.

describe: To grip something is to hold it very tightly.
sample: → I was scared, so I gripped my older sister’s hand.

describe: To halt is to stop moving.
sample: → The criminal halted when he saw the police coming.

describe: If something is impending, it is going to happen soon.
sample: → The student was nervous about his impending test.

describe: To influence someone or something is to have an effect over them.
sample: → My friend influenced my decision to attend Terrance University.

describe: A law is a rule made by the legislative body.
sample: → The students learned about different laws during social studies class.

describe: A mode is a setting or condition on a machine.
sample: → Mother turned the TV to quiet mode while she talked on the phone.

describe: To perspire means to sweat.
sample: → I usually perspire a lot when I am at practice.

describe: To replace something is to put it in the place of something else.
sample: → I replaced the tire on my car because it was flat.

describe: To snap something means to break it suddenly, which causes a loud noise.
sample: → I took the stick and snapped it with my hands.

describe: If a person or animal is sly, they are sneaky or good at tricking people.
sample: → The sly fox stole the eggs from the nest.

describe: To tend to do something is to be likely to do it or to do it often.
sample: → My mom tends to buy me the perfect gift each Christmas.

describe: When something is valid, it is correct or based on good reasoning.
sample: → The expert’s opinion on the subject was more valid than others.

describe: A version is an account of something that differs slightly from the original.
sample: → She read the students British version of the Chinese fairy tale.

describe: You use whatsoever after a noun to emphasize that there is nothing of that thing.
sample: → The boy had no idea whatsoever how to solve the story problem.

describe: If something is alongside another thing, then it is next to it.
sample: → We work alongside each other in the office.

describe: Your appetite is your hunger for food.
sample: → Tom has a big appetite. He eats all the time.

describe: To assist someone is to help them.
sample: → Andrew assisted me with my homework.

describe: A breeze is a soft wind.
sample: → The breeze caused the leaves to fall off the tree.

describe: To defy someone is to work against them or refuse to do what they say.
sample: → The students got into trouble for defying their teacher’s rules.

describe: To display something is to show it, especially by putting it in a certain place.
sample: → The museum displayed many wonderful paintings.

describe: If something or someone is efficient, they do not waste energy.
sample: → My car is very efficient. I rarely have to buy gas.

describe: If someone is feeble, they are small or weak.
sample: → The boy was too feeble to carry the object very far.

describe: To forgive someone is to stop being angry with them.
sample: → Sandra forgave Peter after he said he was sorry.

describe: If someone is lively, they have a lot of energy.
sample: → Jennifer is very lively: she’s always running and playing.

describe: If something is majestic, it is large and beautiful.
sample: → The rich people lived in a big, majestic house.

describe: You use nor to connect two negative ideas.
sample: → I eat neither apples nor oranges. I don’t like either one.

describe: If someone is outraged, they are very angry.
sample: → My father was outraged when he saw that I had crashed his car.

describe: If someone is pessimistic, they believe that the worst will happen.
sample: → John is pessimistic. He always thinks something bad will happen.

describe: A rumor is something people talk about even though it may not be true.
sample: → Kevin was spreading rumors about Marcia to everyone.

describe: To slap someone means to hit them with the palm of the hand.
sample: → Out of anger, Helen slapped Eunice on the face.

describe: To smash something is to break it into many small pieces.
sample: → Jacob smashed the window with a rock.

describe: A subject is the topic that is being discussed or taught.
sample: → The subject of Marco’s speech was the economy.

describe: A wage is the money that a person gets for doing a job.
sample: → The wages I receive from my job are really great!

describe: You use whereas to show how two things are different.
sample: → My sister loves horror movies, whereas I prefer comedies.

describe: When something is animate, it has life.
sample: → Rocks and machines are not animate things.

describe: To classify things is to put them into groups based on their type.
sample: → The biologist classified the plant as a completely new species.

describe: To concede is to admit that something is true against your wish.
sample: → The student conceded that he had cheated on the test.

describe: A concept is an idea about something.
sample: → I learned some concepts of molecules before working in the science lab.

describe: To construct something means to make or build it.
sample: → The men used wood and metal to construct a house.

describe: A decade is a period often years.
sample: → She celebrated her three decades of work with the company.

describe: A diagram is a simple drawing that explains what something is or how it works.
sample: → By following the diagram, I was able to put the desk together.

describe: A ferry is a boat that carries passengers over short distances.
sample: → The ferry took the people across the lake.

describe: If something is handy, it is useful.
sample: → An eraser is handy if you make a lot of mistakes.

describe: To isolate is to separate one person or thing from a group.
sample: → The teacher isolated the bad child from the class before talking with her.

describe: A longing is a strong feeling of wanting.
sample: → Since he skipped breakfast, he had a longing for food all morning.

describe: If something is numerous, there are many of those things.
sample: → It was hard to drive fast since there were numerous holes in the road.

describe: A particle is a very small piece of something.
sample: → The bottles of wine were covered in a layer of dust particles.

describe: A plea is a request that is urgent or emotional.
sample: → The poor, hungry man made a plea for food.

describe: To refrain from something is to avoid doing it.
sample: → The doctor asked Mary to refrain from eating fast food as part of her diet.

describe: A review of something is a formal inspection of it by people in authority.
sample: → The government ordered a careful review of the economic situation.

describe: If someone is sophisticated, they know many things about the world.
sample: → Jake is one of the most sophisticated persons I’ve ever met.

describe: To surrender something is to give it up.
sample: → The thief surrendered the money to the police when he was caught.

describe: If something is upright, it is standing up straight.
sample: → Meerkats can’t walk like humans, but they can stand upright.

describe: If something is worthwhile, it is important or useful.
sample: → On his visit to Canada, he realized studying English was worthwhile.

describe: An alliance is a group of people who work together.
sample: → The junior executives formed an alliance with each other.

describe: Applause is the noise made when people clap hands to show approval.
sample: → At the end of his speech, everyone gave applause.

describe: If you are armed, you are carrying a weapon.
sample: → The robber was armed with a gun.

describe: If something is authoritative, it uses the best information available.
sample: → This book is an authoritative source on Ancient Egypt’s Queen Nefertiti.

describe: A ceremony is an event that happens on special occasions.
sample: → Tom and Amy’s marriage ceremony is in June.

describe: Culture is the music, art, and writings of a certain place or group of people.
sample: → Ancient Mexican culture is renowned for its architecture.

describe: A defense is something that is done to protect another thing.
sample: → The airforce works in defense of its country.

describe: A detail is a small piece of information.
sample: → Jane told Ben all the details of her trip to China.

describe: When a group of things is diverse, it is made up of a wide variety of things.
sample: → Big cities have diverse populations with people of different races and ages.

describe: To enchant someone is to make them feel very interested or happy.
sample: → The beautiful woman enchanted everybody in the room.

describe: To equip someone is to give them the things needed to do something.
sample: → Steve was equipped with the tools needed to do the job.

describe: An exception is someone or something not conforming to a rule.
sample: → Most students thought the test was hard, but Tim was the exception.

describe: A genre is a type of literature, art, or music characterized by its style.
sample: → She is considered a master in the comedy genre.

describe: An impact is the effect someone or something has on another.
sample: → My grandmother had a great impact on my life.

describe: To lure someone is to convince them to do something, by using a trick.
sample: → The store lures people in with big signs that say “Sale!”

describe: An obstacle is an object or a problem that stops you from doing something.
sample: → Climbing over the giant rock was the biggest obstacle for the hikers.

describe: A shelter is a place to go that is safe from danger or bad weather.
sample: → The frog took shelter from the storm in a nearby cave.

describe: To sort means to separate things into different groups or classes.
sample: → He sorted his clothes by colors and sizes.

describe: To supply something means to give people what they need or want.
sample: → The water heater supplied the house with warm water.

describe: If people are vain, they are only concerned with how they look.
sample: → Rebecca is so vain that she looks at herself in every mirror.

describe: An alternative is something that you can choose instead of your first choice.
sample: → Her first plan to make extra money seemed weak, so she chose an alternative.

describe: An avenue is a road, often a large one with buildings on each side.
sample: → Drive down this avenue and then turn left to go to the park.

describe: The belly is the stomach of a person or animal.
sample: → His belly was full because he ate a lot of food.

describe: A bid to do something is an attempt to do it.
sample: → He made a bid to become the university’s next president.

describe: To blow means to move air or move something through the air, as in the wind.
sample: → The wind is blowing very hard today. We should stay inside.

describe: A conflict is a fight between different people or groups.
sample: → The two nations had a conflict over which one could use the water in the river.

describe: A continent is one of the seven large areas of land on the Earth.
sample: → Asia is the largest continent.

describe: A current is a steady and constant flow of air or water in a river or ocean.
sample: → The ocean currents took the ship far off into the sea.

describe: Disrespect is rudeness or a behavior that shows a lack of respect.
sample: → He showed disrespect by arguing with his boss during a meeting.

describe: Enthusiasm is a very strong good feeling about something.
sample: → The crowd showed their enthusiasm for the soccer team by cheering loudly.

describe: When something is harsh, it is very unpleasant.
sample: → The desert can be a very harsh environment.

describe: To lean is to bend the body in a particular direction.
sample: → The woman leaned against the counter because she was tired.

describe: The meantime is the time between two events.
sample: → Ted began setting the table. In the meantime, I began preparing the food.

describe: Mischief is behavior that is meant to trick or cause trouble for people.
sample: → Ben was up to mischief when he persuaded Ken to paint his face.

describe: Muscle is a mass of tissue attached to bone that helps you move.
sample: → She went to the gym in order to make her muscles stronger.

describe: To rescue someone means to remove them from danger.
sample: → The firefighter rescued the man from the burning building.

describe: A succession is a number of things that follow one after the other.
sample: → The student said the letters of the alphabet in succession.

describe: The terrain is the land and all of its physical features or parts.
sample: → The terrain below was rocky and full of hills.

describe: If someone is timid, they are afraid, shy, or nervous.
sample: → The timid child hides behind her mother whenever she sees a stranger.

describe: Violence is forceful action that is meant to injure or kill people.
sample: → The boy hit his brother in an act of violence.

describe: To affect someone or something is to have an influence over them.
sample: → The student’s poor attitude affected the other students in the class.

describe: An autograph is the written name of a famous person.
sample: → Everybody wanted the movie star’s autograph.

describe: A bead is a drop of liquid.
sample: → Beads of water collected outside the glass.

describe: To brew coffee or tea means to pour hot water over it.
sample: → Please brew a fresh pot of coffee.

describe: To charm someone is to please them with your personality.
sample: → Gail charmed everyone with her humorous stories.

describe: A destiny is all the things that happen or will happen to a person in their life.
sample: → It was his destiny to become a great singer.

describe: A horn is a device that makes a loud noise.
sample: → The boy honked his horn while he rode his bicycle past the house.

describe: When someone is irritable, they become annoyed or angry very easily.
sample: → She is irritable when she doesn’t get enough sleep.

describe: To lag behind is to move slowly behind other moving objects.
sample: → The girl on rollerblades lagged behind the little girl on the bicycle.

describe: To maximize something means to make it the biggest in size or amount.
sample: → Businesses try to maximize their profits.

describe: A nightmare is a bad or scary dream.
sample: → The girl was scared to go back to sleep because she had a nightmare.

describe: When something is nutritious, it helps the body stay healthy.
sample: → Mangoes are one of the most nutritious fruits in the world.

describe: Protein is a substance that is necessary for the body to grow and be strong.
sample: → Fish and beef are good sources of protein.

describe: A signature is your name that you have written in your own way.
sample: → I put my signature at the end of the letter.

describe: Stuff is a word used to refer to things without mentioning the things by name.
sample: → We gave a lot of stuff to the charity.

describe: When something is subconscious, it is done without thinking about it.
sample: → Breathing is one of the subconscious things that the body does.

describe: A van is a vehicle that is used for carrying things but is smaller than a truck.
sample: → The delivery company uses large vans to deliver packages.

describe: To warn someone is to make them know of possible danger in the future.
sample: → The lifeguard warned people to stay away from the rough ocean.

describe: A workout is an exercise routine that helps improve health.
sample: → She doesn’t do her workout on the weekends.

describe: To zoom is to move quickly.
sample: → The cars zoomed along the road.

describe: A brick is a block of hard clay that is used for building things, such as walls.
sample: → There were several bricks scattered on the ground.

describe: To crumble means to break or fall apart into small pieces.
sample: → The old house’s walls crumbled into a pile of rock and wood.

describe: Dough is a mixture of flour and water that becomes bread when baked.
sample: → I made heart-shaped cookies from the dough.

describe: To express a feeling or idea means to show others how one thinks or feels.
sample: → The nurse expressed her sympathy for the sick patient.

describe: A fist is a hand with fingers bent in toward the palm.
sample: → The bully made a fist and threatened to hit the small boy.

describe: If something is flexible, then it can bend easily without breaking.
sample: → The tree branch was so flexible it could be bent into a circle and not break.

describe: To flush means the face becomes red due to heat, illness, or emotion.
sample: → After the long race, the runner’s face was flushed.

describe: To injure someone means to damage a part of their body.
sample: → The car crash injured two people.

describe: A lump is a small piece of something that is solid.
sample: → The artist took a lump of clay and turned it into a beautiful pot.

describe: A mixture is something that is made by mixing other things together.
sample: → The walls were built using a mixture of water, rock, and dirt.

describe: To reconcile means to return to a friendly relationship.
sample: → After arguing, the two friends were reconciled with each other.

describe: To ruin something means to harm or damage it greatly.
sample: → Our walk in the park was ruined by the sudden rain.

describe: To shatter something means to break it suddenly into many tiny pieces.
sample: → When the ball hit the window, the glass shattered.

describe: Shutters are wooden or metal covers in front of a window.
sample: → Mr. Smith closed the shutters every night to make his bedroom dark.

describe: To sift something means to remove all the large pieces.
sample: → The baker sifted the flour into a large bowl.

describe: If something is slight, then it is small or minor.
sample: → There was only a slight change in the little boy’s height.

describe: To sparkle means to shine brightly with quick flashes of light.
sample: → The stars sparkled in the winter night’s sky.

describe: To sprinkle means to scatter something all over something else.
sample: → He sprinkled the pasta with salt and black pepper.

describe: If food is stale, then it is not fresh but dry, hard, and not good to eat.
sample: → The cookies sat on the table so long that they became stale.

describe: To utter a word or a sound means to say it.
sample: → The lost boy was so scared that he could barely utter a single word.

describe: You use although to say that one thing is contrasted by another.
sample: → Although she was late, her friends gave her a warm welcome.

describe: To apply something means to put it on.
sample: → She always applies makeup to her face before going outside.

describe: To await something means to wait for it.
sample: → The players awaited the judge’s decision.

describe: When something is beloved, it is very special and you like it very much.
sample: → The boy took a nap next to his beloved cat.

describe: To bury someone or something means to put them in the ground.
sample: → They buried their grandfather under his favorite tree after he died.

describe: A climate is the usual weather in a place.
sample: → The climate in the desert is very hot.

describe: When you complain, you say that you are unhappy about something.
sample: → The workers complained that they were being treated unfairly.

describe: To confuse someone means to make them feel like they are unsure.
sample: → The sign confused the traveler because it pointed in two directions.

describe: When something is due, it is expected to happen or be done at that time.
sample: → The papers were due on the 19th.

describe: When you talk about an entire thing, you are talking about the whole thing.
sample: → He was so hungry that he ate the entire pizza by himself.

describe: To establish something means to create it.
sample: → He wanted to establish a club for people to help the Earth.

describe: A furnace is a place where heat is made.
sample: → Mr. Jones came to fix the furnace.

describe: A leash is a rope or chain that is used to lead an animal.
sample: → A lot of dogs must wear a leash to keep them from running away.

describe: To mature means to grow up to become an adult.
sample: → When they matured, they became as tall as their parents.

describe: To measure something means to find out the quality, value, or effect of it.
sample: → The scientists carefully measured the amount of chemicals in the tubes.

describe: The midst of something is the middle of it.
sample: → She was in the midst of cleaning when the telephone rang.

describe: Misery is extreme suffering.
sample: → There was a lot of misery after Sam lost his dog.

describe: When something happened prior to something else, it happened earlier.
sample: → Ron had to wait since he arrived prior to the scheduled meeting time.

describe: Research is close and careful study to discover new things.
sample: → Scientists did a lot of research on the subject of blood type.

describe: A variety of something is a group of many different kinds of it.
sample: → There are a variety of flowers at the shop.

describe: If something happens altogether, it happens completely.
sample: → The company stopped using sugar altogether in its food.

describe: To bind is to bring people together.
sample: → The victims of the flood were bound by their need to help each other.

describe: A bruise is a dark mark caused by being hit by something.
sample: → She got a bruise on her knee from falling down.

describe: A custom is a way of doing things that has been the same for a long time.
sample: → It is a custom that the bride and groom have the first dance.

describe: When someone is disobedient, they do not follow the rules or instructions.
sample: → The disobedient children didn’t listen to their mother and had an accident.

describe: To foresee something is to know about it before it happens.
sample: → The teacher didn’t foresee any problems with her large class.

describe: To glimpse something is to see it for a short time.
sample: → She glimpsed outside the window as the plane was about to land.

describe: A hoop is a ring that is made of plastic, metal, or wood.
sample: → The boys tried to toss the ball through the basketball hoop.

describe: Misfortune is bad luck or an unlucky event.
sample: → His family helped him when he encountered misfortune.

describe: When something is negative, it is unpleasant or sad.
sample: → She doesn’t like to say negative things about her friends.

describe: Per is used to mean “each” when giving a price, size, or amount.
sample: → It costs $8 per person to watch the baseball game.

describe: To plead is to ask for something you want very badly.
sample: → He pleaded for his parents to let him go to the soccer game.

describe: To rip something means to pull it apart.
sample: → She ripped the paper in half by accident.

describe: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
sample: → The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.

describe: To scrape something is to rub it very hard with something sharp.
sample: → I accidentally scraped the paint off the side of the car.

describe: A source of something is the place that it comes from.
sample: → The river was the source of drinking water for the village.

describe: When somebody is stern, they are very serious.
sample: → The stern teacher didn’t allow the students to speak during class.

describe: To stitch is to use a needle and thread to join pieces of cloth together.
sample: → My grandmother stitched the pieces together to make a big blanket.

describe: A thump is the sound of a heavy object falling.
sample: → They heard the thump when the bowling ball hit the floor.

describe: When somebody is vehement, they are angry and emotional.
sample: → Gina was vehement when she found out that Liz was bad in school.

describe: A civilization is an organized group of humans that have culture and government.
sample: → Most early civilizations in Central America didn’t use metal weapons.

describe: When something is convenient, it is easy to do and does not take a lot of work.
sample: → The bus is a convenient way to get to school.

describe: A den is a living space for some types of animals, such as lions.
sample: → The mother lion left her babies in the den.

describe: Dew is the drops of water that form on the ground outside during the night.
sample: → When we woke up, we saw that the grass was covered in dew.

describe: When something is drastic, it is extreme or major.
sample: → She made a drastic decision to get her long hair cut short.

describe: To exit means to leave.
sample: → The students exited through the front door.

describe: A flock is a group of animals, such as birds, sheep or goats.
sample: → There was one black sheep in the entire flock.

describe: To fold is to bend something like paper or cloth so that it takes up less space.
sample: → I folded the paper and put it in my pocket.

describe: A lid is a top for a box or container that can be removed.

describe: To loom is to seem very large and often scary.
sample: → The ominous clouds loomed over the school.

describe: When something is mighty, it is strong and large.
sample: → The mighty wrestler scared all who faced him.

describe: A mushroom is a fungus with a round top. Some are used as food.
sample: → The soup had fresh mushrooms in it.

describe: When something is native, it is originating in a certain place or area.
sample: → Avocadoes are native fruits of Mexico.

describe: Poison is a dangerous substance that causes illness or death.
sample: → They used poison to get rid of the rats in their home.

describe: Reeds are tall and skinny plants that grow in groups near water.
sample: → The sun set behind the reeds of the lake’s shore.

describe: To shield something is to protect it.
sample: → She shielded her eyes from the sun with sunglasses.

describe: Stormy describes something affected or characterized by storms.
sample: → The golfers decided to go home because of the stormy weather.

describe: To sway is to move slowly from side to side.
sample: → She swayed while she listened to the music.

describe: When something is urban, it is related to the city.
sample: → Subways are an important form of urban transportation.

describe: To wade is to walk in or pass through water.
sample: → The child waded in the water at the beach.

describe: An accent is a certain way of speaking that shows where a person is from.
sample: → The new teacher’s accent was clearly a German one.

describe: A barber is a person whose job is to cut hair.
sample: → My hair is getting much too long. I’d better go to the barber’s shop.

describe: A basement of a house or building is a room that is built underground.
sample: → They turned their basement into a game room.

describe: When something is blank, it does not have anything on it.
sample: → She got a blank paper to draw on.

describe: To blink means to shut the eyes and quickly open them again.
sample: → I blinked many times so that my eyes could adjust to the bright light.

describe: A choir is a group of people who sing together.
sample: → He had choir practice every day after school.

describe: When something is comic, it is funny.
sample: → The comic actor was famous for his jokes.

describe: To complicate something means to make it harder than necessary.
sample: → The bad weather complicated finishing the job quickly.

describe: To decline an offer or invitation means to say no to it.
sample: → She declined his offer to pay for her dinner.

describe: An errand is a trip taken to do a specific activity.
sample: → He couldn’t go to practice because he had several errands to do.

describe: A glove is a piece of clothing that covers your fingers and hand.
sample: → When it gets cold, I always put on a pair of gloves.

describe: A hermit is one who lives alone and does not spend time with others.
sample: → The hermit lived a simple life in a small cave in the forest.

describe: If something is done justly, then it is fair.
sample: → We justly decided to give the prize to him.

describe: Leather is a material made from animal skin that is used to make clothing.
sample: → He got a new leather jacket for his birthday.

describe: To ponder something is to think about it carefully.
sample: → She sat in the park and pondered her problem.

describe: To reserve something means to keep it for a certain person or time.

describe: A script is the words of a film or play.
sample: → He read the script of the play three times.

describe: To search for something or someone means to look for them carefully.
sample: → I searched the newspaper for a new job.

describe: To slam is to close something hard.
sample: → She slammed the book shut after she finished reading it.

describe: A staircase is a set of stairs found inside a building.
sample: → The staircase leads directly into the kitchen.

describe: Afflicted means to suffer physically or mentally.
sample: → He was afflicted by pain in his right arm.

describe: An aisle is a space between two things that people use to walk.
sample: → They were told to clear the aisle because the plane was about to land.

describe: The atmosphere is the air around the Earth where weather conditions form.
sample: → Scientists worry that harmful substances are hurting the atmosphere.

describe: An author is a person who wrote a certain piece of writing.
sample: → The author was hard at work on his next novel.

describe: A breakdown is a failure to work correctly.
sample: → Her car had a breakdown, and she wasn’t sure how to fix it.

describe: Cargo is the items carried by a ship or airplane.
sample: → The cargo of the ship got wet when it started raining.

describe: A chapter is a part of a book that usually has a number or a title.

describe: To connect two things means to join them together.
sample: → I connected the mouse to my laptop computer.

describe: Etc. is short for “etcetera.” It is used to refer to other unspecified objects.
sample: → She was going to bring treats to the party: cookies, muffins, cake, etc.

describe: To flip means to press a switch quickly to turn it on or off.

describe: If you are idle, you are not doing anything.

describe: To notify someone of something is to tell them about it.

describe: Peas are a vegetable that is small, round and green.
sample: → His favorite food was peas.

describe: A raisin is a dried grape.
sample: → Raisins are one of my favorite snacks.

describe: To retain something is to keep it.

describe: To state something means to say it in a definite way.
sample: → The president stated his opinion about the world’s health concerns.

describe: A tray is a flat plate used to hold food.
sample: → The waiter brought our food on a tray.

describe: If something is unfortunate, it is bad or unlucky.
sample: → It was unfortunate that Dave’s team lost, but he still had fun.

describe: When something is vivid, it is bright and colorful.
sample: → The figures in the painting were vivid.

describe: To vomit means to have food come up from one’s stomach.
sample: → It is common for women to vomit when they are pregnant.

describe: To betray someone means to treat them in a dishonest way.

describe: A blast is a loud noise made by something that explodes.

describe: A bracelet is a piece of jewelry that you wear around your wrist.
sample: → My father gave me a pretty gold bracelet for my birthday.

describe: To cease means to stop.

describe: To choke means to cough because you have difficulty breathing.

describe: To comment means to say something that shows your personal opinion.

describe: To cross means to go from one side to the other side.

describe: A dent is damage caused by something heavy hitting something else.
sample: → That blue car hit my car, and now there is a small dent in my car door.

describe: To distrust someone means to believe that they are not honest.
sample: → Don’t lend money to someone if you distrust them!

describe: A fort is a small building that is specially built to defend an area from attack.

describe: To found means to bring something into existence.
sample: → The pastor founded his church in the countryside.

describe: Lining is a piece of cloth that covers the inside of clothes.
sample: → This jacket is very warm because it has a thick lining.

describe: A mass is a large number of things of one type.

describe: To pray means to talk to God.
sample: → When people go to church, they pray for their families and friends.

describe: If a place is rife with something bad, it is very common in that place.

describe: When something is the sole thing, it is the only thing of a particular type.
sample: → His sole purpose in life was to help others.

describe: If you sweep the floor, you clean it with a tool like a broom or a brush.

describe: Treachery is a behavior in which a person betrays a country or a person.

describe: To tuck something means to put it somewhere so that it is neat or safe.
sample: → He looked sloppy without his shirt being tucked into his pants.

describe: A background is a person’s education, family, and experience.
sample: → The new teacher had a background in science and math.

describe: Bait is something used to trick a person or thing to do something.
sample: → The best bait for catching fish is a big, fat worm.

describe: To chronicle something means to record an event or speech.
sample: → The daily newspaper chronicles local and world events.

describe: Copper is a red-brown metal often used in electric wire and pipes.
sample: → Ancient hunters melted copper to make knives and spears.

describe: A disease is an illness that causes specific problems.
sample: → He had a disease that caused him to lose his hearing.

describe: Folklore is the collection of beliefs and stories of a culture.
sample: → India’s folklore has stories written in long poems about great warriors.

describe: To infect someone means to give them an illness.
sample: → The common cold infects hundreds of millions of people each year.

describe: To itch means to rub the skin with your fingernails.
sample: → The rough fabric in his shirt made the back of his neck itch.

describe: Literature is books, plays, and poetry.
sample: → Early American literature covers the poetry and stories from 1500 to 1800.

describe: A millennium is one thousand years.
sample: → Stonehenge is believed to have been built about 5 millenniums ago.

describe: A myth is a traditional story that explains a culture’s history and beliefs.
sample: → In Greece, there was a myth about a woman who had snakes for hair.

describe: To relate to something means to have a connection with it.

describe: A religion is a belief in a god or gods.

describe: A sum is a specific amount of money.
sample: → He calculated the numbers to see what the sum of his bills would be.

describe: A teller is a person who works with a bank’s customers.
sample: → The teller at the bank helped Kelly put money into a savings account.

describe: If someone is trustworthy, they are honest and truthful.
sample: → Mary is one of the most trustworthy people I’ve ever met.

describe: To update something means to make it more modern.
sample: → We need to update the programs on our computers.

describe: A vein is a tube in the body that carries blood toward the heart.
sample: → The blue veins in my hand are just under my skin.

describe: Venom is a poisonous substance that comes from animals or plants.
sample: → A snake’s venom can be used to cure the illnesses it creates.

describe: To promote someone means to raise them to a higher position or rank.
sample: → After two years in the company, she was promoted to a manager.

describe: Charity is an act of giving help, usually money, to those who need it.
sample: → Thanks to his friends’ charity, he had enough money to pay the rent.

describe: Commerce is the activity of buying and selling things.
sample: → The new shopping mall increased the commerce in that section of town.

describe: To condemn someone means to give them a specific punishment.
sample: → The judge condemned the criminal to five years in prison.

describe: If something is cozy, then it is comfortable, warm, and relaxing.
sample: → The thick blanket made the bed very cozy.

describe: To deplete an amount of something means to use up all of it.

describe: An economy is the money and businesses of a country or region.

describe: An empire is a large group of countries ruled by an emperor or empress.
sample: → The emperor built roads to make travel easier throughout the empire.

describe: Goods are anything that can be bought or sold.

describe: To heed something means to obey or follow it.
sample: → You should heed the advice on the sign and not drive so fast.

describe: To hitchhike means to travel by asking for rides from passing vehicles.
sample: → She didn’t have a car, so she hitchhiked several miles to her brother’s home.

describe: To mock someone means to tease them in a cruel way.

describe: If someone is neutral, then they do not help either of the two fighting sides.

describe: To persecute means to treat someone badly.
sample: → Dan felt persecuted because he was smaller than the other boys at school.

describe: Pity is the feeling of sadness and kindness for those who are suffering.
sample: → Because she had pity for the lost boy, she helped him find his parents.

describe: To reduce something means to make it less in size or number.
sample: → When the store reduced its prices, people wanted to shop there.

describe: A scribe was a person whose job was to copy written works.
sample: → In Ancient Egypt, scribes recorded important events.

describe: A temper is someone’s mood or a chance that they might get angry.
sample: → She has a temper. Even the slightest mistakes make her angry.

describe: A throne is the special chair in which a ruler sits.
sample: → Nobody except the king and queen sat in the thrones in the great hall.

describe: Unity is the state of people working together for a certain purpose.
sample: → The project was finished early, thanks to the unity of the workers.

describe: A victor is a group or person that wins in a contest.
sample: → At the end of the game, the blue team was the victor.

describe: If something is accurate, it is completely correct.
sample: → The story in the newspaper wasn’t very accurate.

describe: To analyze something is to study it.
sample: → The scientist will analyze the blood sample.

describe: An asteroid is a giant rock from outer space.
sample: → In 1908, a giant asteroid hit Siberia.

describe: A controversy is a dispute about something that affects many people.
sample: → There has been a lot of controversy over the judge’s decision.

describe: To evolve is to change over time.
sample: → Many people think that humans evolved from animals.

describe: A factor is something that has an effect on the way another thing happens.
sample: → Smoking is the main factor that causes lung cancer.

describe: If something is genetic, it is related to the genes in one’s body.
sample: → The color of one’s eyes is genetic.

describe: To be identical is to be the same as someone or something else.

describe: An intellectual is a very smart person.

describe: A majority of something is almost all of the people or things in that group.

describe: To multiply is to increase in number.

describe: Offspring are the children of a person or the babies of an animal.
